title: Metrics and Traces via OpenTelemetry
description:
Enables metrics and traces using OpenTelemetry.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

service_name.title: Service Name
service_name.description:
A friendly name identifying metrics reported by this installation. When unset, it uses the `name` attribute in the root level.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

layers.title: Layers
layers.description:
Lets you specify what data you want to export. All layers are enabled by default unless you declare this section. This is the more granular layer.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

backend.title: Report backend activity
backend.description:
Reports the activity between KrakenD and each of your backend services

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

disable_stage.title: Disable this stage
disable_stage.description:
Whether to disable the full metrics stage for this backend or not.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

round_trip.title: Disable global trace
round_trip.description:
Whether you want to enable metrics for the actual HTTP request for the backend or not (manipulation not taken into account).

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

read_payload.title: Disable propagation
read_payload.description:
Whether you want to enable metrics for the response reading payload or not (HTTP connection not taken into account).

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

detailed_connection.title: Disable propagation
detailed_connection.description:
Whether you want to enable metrics for the response reading payload or not (HTTP connection not taken into account).

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

static_attributes.title: Static attributes
static_attributes.description:
A list of tags or labels you want to associate to these metrics.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

key.title: Key
key.description:
The key, tag, or label name you want to use.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

value.title: Value
value.description:
The static value you want to assign to this key.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

disable_stage.title: Disable this stage
disable_stage.description:
Whether to disable the full traces stage for this backend or not.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

round_trip.title: Disable global trace
round_trip.description:
Whether you want to enable traces for the actual HTTP request for the backend or not (manipulation not taken into account).

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

read_payload.title: Disable propagation
read_payload.description:
Whether you want to enable traces for the response reading payload or not (HTTP connection not taken into account).

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

detailed_connection.title: Disable propagation
detailed_connection.description:
Whether you want to enable traces for the response reading payload or not (HTTP connection not taken into account).

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

static_attributes.title: Static attributes
static_attributes.description:
A list of tags or labels you want to associate to these traces.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

key.title: Key
key.description:
The key, tag, or label name you want to use.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

value.title: Value
value.description:
The static value you want to assign to this key.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

global.title: Report global activity
global.description:
Reports the activity between end-users and KrakenD

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

disable_metrics.title: Disable global metrics
disable_metrics.description:
Whether you want to disable all metrics happening in the global layer or not.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

disable_traces.title: Disable global trace
disable_traces.description:
Whether you want to disable all traces happening in the global layer or not.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

disable_propagation.title: Disable propagation
disable_propagation.description:
Whether you want to disable the consumption of propagation headers all traces happening in the global layer or not (so spans from a previous layer are linked to the KrakenD trace).

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

proxy.title: Report proxy activity
proxy.description:
Reports the activity at the beginning of the proxy layer, including spawning the required requests to multiple backends, merging, endpoint transformation and any other internals of the proxy between the request processing and the backend communication

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

disable_metrics.title: Disable proxy metrics
disable_metrics.description:
Whether you want to disable all metrics happening in the proxy layer or not.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

disable_traces.title: Disable proxy trace
disable_traces.description:
Whether you want to disable all traces happening in the proxy layer or not.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

exporters.title: Exporters
exporters.description:
The different kind of exporters you are configuring.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

prometheus.title: Prometheus exporter
prometheus.description:
Set here at least the settings for one Prometheus exporter. Each exporter will start a local port that offers metrics to be pulled from KrakenD.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

name.title: Name
name.description:
A name to identify this exporter. The exporter's name is referenced in the `instance` section.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

listen_ip.title: Listen IP
listen_ip.description: The IP address that KrakenD listens to in IPv4 or IPv6. You can for instance, expose the prometheus metrics only in a private IP address. An empty string, or no declaration at all means listening on all interfaces. The inclusion of `::` is meant for IPv6 format only (**this is not the port**). Examples of valid addresses are `192.0.2.1` (IPv4), `2001:db8::68` (IPv6). The values `::` and `0.0.0.0` listen to all addresses and both are valid for IPv4 and IPv6 simultaneously.

port.title: Port
port.description:
The port where this exporters communicates.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

process_metrics.title: Process Metrics?
process_metrics.description:
Whether this exporter must process metrics or not.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

go_metrics.title: Go Metrics?
go_metrics.description:
Whether you want fine-grained details of Go language metrics or not.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

otlp.title: OTLP exporter
otlp.description:
Set here the settings to push metrics and traces to an external collector using OTLP.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

name.title: Name
name.description:
A name to identify this exporter. The exporter's name is referenced in the `instance` section.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

host.title: Host
host.description:
The host where you want to push the data. It can be a sidecar or a remote collector.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

use_http.title: Use HTTP
use_http.description:
Whether this exporter uses HTTP instead of gRPC.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

port.title: Port
port.description:
A custom port to send the data. The port defaults to 4317 for gRPC, unless you enable `use_http` which defaults to 4318.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/

skip_paths.title: Skip Paths
skip_paths.description:
The paths you don't want to report. Use the literal value used in the `endpoint` definition, including any `{placeholders}`.

See: https://www.krakend.io/docs/telemetry/opentelemetry/
